commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message: Add info about starting the server
commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.
A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message:
Allow registration

This simple change enables registration. It's not very flexible but it's
okay for the start. Registration is available at /register and via a
link on the login page.
commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message:
Add run-blog word

This will make our life so much easier.

<alloy> makes several things. First it "associates" a database file to
our dispatcher. Second it initializes Furnace sessions and more which
will help in the future.

Then we set the main-responder symbol globally to our dispatcher and
last we start a http server listening on port 8080.
commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message:
Split layout into boilerplate and page

So, I split the layout template because the auth stuff has got its own
boilerplate templates and this caused a double h1 on /login. This
restructuring now also keeps the real boilerplate like html, body tags
etc seperate from page layout stuff.
commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message:
Move new post link to recent-posts template

If we keep it in layout.xml it will result in ugly errors when accessing
/login. recent-posts is more fitting anyway.
commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message:
Add authentication

Thanks to furnace.auth.login we have almost no work to add
authentication to the blog. We only need to wrap our dispatcher in the
<blog> word by a login-realm. <login-realm> expects a name and a
dispatcher on the stack, name being on top.

I don't have a SSL cert so I have to switch off https by setting secure
to f.

<login-realm> provides our dispatcher with additional "/login" and
"/logout" paths.
commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.
A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.
A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message:
Add delete link to view-post template

This shouldn't need an explanation, see the link the line above for
reference.
commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message:
Add <delete-post-action> word

This time, we don't use a page-action but an action. page-actions have
an extra template slot which is of no use here because we won't display
anything. Notice we will receive the id by the url and not as an POST
parameter. This is just for simplicity's sake, if we run into problems,
we can still fix them later.
commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message:
Add edit link to view-post template

This should really be nothing new.
commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message:
Add <edit-post-action> and <submit-post-action>

<edit-post-action> does the same as <view-post-action> but uses a
different template so we can just create a new <new-post-action> and
change its template slot.

<submit-post-action> is very similar to <new-post-action> but here its
not possible to reuse <new-post-action> without much extra code so I
just do it the old way. Everything should be familiar here though.

Now for the reason we need to different actions. When we access
/edit-post/1 through a GET request the "id" value is set to 1 because of
the rest slot of <edit-post-action>. But when we access /edit-post
through a POST request (which we would if we wrote
t:action="$blog/edit-post" in the template) Furnace gets confused
because we don't have a rest in the url which can be used to initialize
"id" so "id" is set to f. Instead we have "id" in our POST parameters
which is read earlier and so is overwritten by the f. Therefore we send
to "$blog/submit-post".
commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message:
Add edit-post template

Everything is the same as the new-post template except for the t:for
attribute of the t:form element. The t:for attribute takes a list of
comma-seperated values which will then be included as hidden fields.

Notice also that we're not sending the post request with the filled form
to the same address as the get request for the form. This is explained
in the next commit.
commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message:
Add <view-post-action> word

Again we're using a page-action but this time we use the additional rest
field. The value of the rest field tells the action where to store the
rest of the url which isn't matched by the dispatcher.

In the init quotation we first make sure the value stored in "id" is an
integer. Next we get that value, query for the post object with that
value as its id. from-object does essentially what t:bind-each does,
with the exception that from object just takes one object and not a
sequence.

Last we add this action to our blog dispatcher in <blog>.

This ends the first part of this gitutorial.
commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message:
Add view-post template

There really shouldn't be anything new anymore. This is just the part
inside of the t:bind-each of the recent-posts template.
commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message:
Add <blog> word

The <blog> word creates a new blog dispatcher. Then it associates the
root path ("/") with the recent-posts action which means everytime the
url "/" is accessed this action will be executed. Next it associates the
"/new-post" url with our new-post action.

Last it wraps the whole dispatcher in a boilerplate object. This
boilerplate is used to factor out the common parts of the templates for
the actions.
commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message:
Add layout template

This is just some boilerplate to serve valid xhtml sites.

Maybe you noticed the gloriously ignored t:title tags in the templates
before, the t:write-title marks the locations where the content of those
tags goes to.

The t:call-next-template tag says "I want my templates to be inserted
right here."
commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message:
Add <new-post-action> word

This action doesn't, unlike the recent-posts action, do anything special
when accessed through a http get request (init field) but has special
quotations for http post requests. The validate and submit quotations
are called when accessed through a http post request (validate first,
then submit).

The validate quotation is quite simple, it just calls validate-post.

The submit quotation has more new stuff. It first creates a new empty
post object and then fills its title and content fields with the values
provided by the html form (remember the t:name="title" in new-post.xml
for example). Then the created-at slot is filled with the current
timestamp. Finally the tuple is written to the db and a redirect
response is pushed onto the stack. The submit quotation always has to
push one response onto the top of the stack.
commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message:
Add post-url word

This is pretty easy. It transforms the id to an string, appends it to
"$blog/post/" (dispatcher-relative path!) and transforms the resulting
string into an url object because it's so much easier to work with url
object in furnace (Factor's web framework).
commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message:
Add validate-post word

It just checks that
  * the title is not empty,
  * the title has no line breaks,
  * the title has at most 100 characters, and
  * the content is not empty.
commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message:
Add new-post template

The t:validation-errors will display a list of validation errors
(pretty self-explaining, isn't it? ;)). We will come to validation in
the next commit.

The t:form works nearly the same as a html form tag. The
"$blog/new-post" has the same meaning as before, it's a
dispatcher-relative path.

t:field:
  a html input, the value is saved in "title", the max. length is 100.

t:text-area:
  a html text-area, the value is saved in "content".
commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message:
Add <recent-posts-action> word

The returned value is a page-action object. When the action is fired,
the 5 most recent posts are fetched and bound to the "posts" value (see
previous commit). The template field is set so the action knows which
template to render.
commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message:
Add recent-posts template

The template works this way:
  We are giving the template a sequence of posts. This sequence
  will be available through the "posts" value in the template.
  The t:bind-each element accesses this sequence because the value
  of its t:name attribute is "posts". The t:bind-each element now
  will call its content for each element in "posts" with the
  current element's id title field bound to "title" and so on.

  The next unclear passage may be the t:a. It works mostly like an
  ordinary html a tag. A difference is the t:href attribute. The
  value in this example is a dispatcher relative path. This means
  the rendered href will be the blog dispatcher's path plus an
  additional "post". The blog dispatcher's path is "/" in this example
  so this just means "/post". Next comes the t:rest attribute. This
  means the rendered path will get an extra value at the end namely the
  current value bound to "id" (remember the t:bind-each). Finaly the
  rendered path will be "/post/1" or "/post/2" or... you get the idea.

  Next comes the t:label. This renders the value currently bound to
  "title".

  The last new passage should be the t:farkup tag. This works the same
  as the t:label tag except it tranforms the value using farkup before.
commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message:
Add blog dispatcher

A dispatcher associates urls our webapp is accessed with to
actions erving responses.
commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message:
Add recent-posts word

recent-posts takes one value from the stack which determines the
maximum number of posts to be returned.

First we transform our post object into a query object. We can now
access our post tuple through the query's tuple field. The great thing
about query object is you can define special query properties like an
order of the result set returned by words like select-tuples.
commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message:
Add post word

I added a "post" word which takes a integer from the stack and pushes
the tuple having this id from the database. Because we now also have a
word named "post" all our references to the class "post" have to be
escaped.
commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message:
Add post tuple

Everything should be familiar here except the define-persistent
passage. What "define-persistent" does is just telling Factor which
field belongs to which database column and defining the types of each
column.

define-persistent takes 3 values from the stack: the class, the
database table name and an array of column definitions on top. A
column definition takes the following form:
       { field-name column-name type extra-info }.
commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message:
First commit

So, I just scaffolded a new vocabulary named "blog". It's still empty
but it will be filled shortly.
commit_list.repo_description: A gitutorial showing how to write a simple blog using Factor's Furnace web framework. At the moment this blog can't do much except creating, listing and viewing posts.

commit_list.message:
Fix Kernel#extend.

Kernel#extend now raises TypeError if self is frozen.

Fixes several Module instance methods.

* Module#public_method_defined?
* Module#private_method_defined?
* Module#protected_method_defined?
* Module#remove_const

Fixes a wrong spec.

The spec caused a error in some cases.

Signed-off-by: Eero Saynatkari <projects@kittensoft.org>

memory leaks fixes

better checks for container emptiness

In cooperation with @burningTyger.
Add German translation of GC docs
Add missing period in GC docs.

ARGF fixes

Fix SortedSet to ensure objects comparable with <=>

Issue 1005 fix
Two members of VMMethod could be public if LLVM was disabled

commit_list.message:
wallet-cli: Do not ask for scan_from_height if it explicitly is set to zero.

Fixes #3080

Give a bonus for having the bishop pair

Slightly inaccurate because if only checks if we have two bishops, not
whether those are actually on opposite color squares.

Games: W: 564 L: 403 D: 335 N: 1302
Elo:   43.18 (+/- 16.33)
SPRT:  2.96 (-2.94, 2.94) [0.0, 5.0]
Fix name in response to uci command

Reduce quiet replies to null moves

Games: W: 787 L: 623 D: 511 N: 1921
Elo: 29.73 +/- 13.33
SPRT: 2.95 (-2.94, 2.94) [0.0, 5.0]

Remove Copy trait from Position

Moves of Copy types result in calls to memcpy. Avoid that by passing
Position by reference where possible and cloning otherwise.

Removing Copy helps to avoid accidental copies (but is not strictly
necessary).

Slight speedup.
Clean up output of tt command
Save to TT in root node
Add min and max value for UCI Hash param
Change default TT size to 1 MB

Sort non-best moves at root by subtree size

Games: W: 2294 L: 2102 D: 1702 N: 6098
Elo:   10.94 (+/- 7.40)
SPRT:  2.96 (-2.94, 2.94) [0.0, 5.0]

Add passed pawn evaluation

Games: W: 481 L: 318 D: 241 N: 1041
Elo:   55.19 (+/- 18.66)
SPRT:  2.96 (-2.94, 2.94)
MovePicker takes a Position instead of a MoveGenerator
Refactor some common code from the search methods
Add and fix clone_on_ref_ptr clippy warning
Make castle rights changes more readable
Add and fix some more clippy warnings

Move::to_algebraic takes self by value

Move is Copy and small, hence this is possible.
Fixes a clippy warning.

Bitboard and Square take self by value

Both are Copy and small (8 and 1 bytes, resp.), hence this is possible.
Fixes some clippy warnings.

Use Duration::subsec_millis()

It became stable in Rust 1.27.
Fixes some clippy warinings.

TTMove methods take self by value

This is possible because TTMove is Copy and small (2 bytes).
Also fixes some clippy warnings.

Encourage king centralization in end game

Elo: 19.02 +/- 10.38 [0.0, 5.0]
SPRT: llr 2.95, lbound -2.94, ubound 2.94
Remove now unnecessary tick parameter of MovePicker
Fix ordering of all moves by subtree size

Do not gen. quiet moves if they would get pruned

Games: W: 448 L: 292 D: 270 N: 1010
Elo:   54.10 (+/- 18.47)
SPRT:  2.95 (-2.94, 2.94) [0.0, 5.0]
Basic AI. Move AI into own module
Basic AI struct. Display possible moves by pressing M.

Split Board into Game and GameState

GameState is Copy which will be nice for future AIs.
Track moves and enable undu by pressing U
ai: use a shallower null window test before a deep search
ai: check if the game is decided
ai: use IncrementalHash table instead of HashMap
ai: add kinds of pieces into evaluation
ai: track updates and replacements in TT
ai: add assert for one implicit assumption
ai: add total number of cutoffs statistic
Clean up and comment parts of src/ai/mod.rs
ai: don't sort the movelist fully
ai: best_move in Transposition is optional
ai: use transposition table only if its depth is higher
ai: track how many moves are explored in each node
Separate AI structs for both sides
ai: track move in transposition table
ai: use iterative deepening and log TT cutoffs

ai: move possible_moves into AI again

This allows the move ordering to depend on the current player
ai: order moves by difference in y
ai: split evaluate_position into evaluate_position and search
ai: Implement an InternalGameState etc using bitboards
Fix GameState::targets and make it static
Move possible_moves from AI into GameState
Change default search depth to 8 plies
Rename reachable_from to moves_from, return Vec<Move>
Split main.rs into lib.rs and bin/gui.rs
ai: transpositions which are too old are replaced
AI play against each other automatically
Encourage pieces on 2nd & 4th row of target area

Improve evaluation by considering piece mobility

Slows down the evaluation heavily but plays much stronger.
Change match length to 300 moves and tournament length to 12 rounds
Change seconds to millis in ai binary

Change win condition slightly

The target area has to be completely covered and has to contain at
least one of the players pieces. This avoids draws because of not
being able to move the last piece outside of the starting area.
Move TT replacement decision into Transposition::should_be_replaced_by
Do not track the individual types of cutoffs
Only cutoff on exact TT entries in PV nodes
ai: Split null-window search into its own function
ai: Only start null-window searches if we increased alpha before
ai: Cache if the stop condition was triggered
Stop increasing depth if we found a winning sequence

ai: Add PV information to search

Only research null-window fail-highs if in PV node.
PV nodes are always inserted into the transposition table.
ai: Add StopCondition to end the search after a fixed duration or depth

Add Depth and Ply type (i32 and u32, resp.)

This means the size of an Option<Transposition> is now 32 bytes which
allows two such objects to fit into a cacheline (assuming a cacheline
size of 64 bytes).
Do not track current game state in TT

Refactor move picking into MovePicker

Also this now easily allows for the moves to only be generated after the
TT moves were tried and did not produce a cutoff.

wallet-cli: Do not ask for scan_from_height if it explicitly is set to zero.

Fixes #3080

repo_list.description: Distributed query processing implemented in Rust
Open Machine Intelligence Framework for Hackers. (GPU/CPU)
Monero: the secure, private, untraceable cryptocurrency
